DataElement.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography Diagnostic Imaging Total Curie Extension Score
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The total cure extension score using PET.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography Diagnostic Imaging Total Curie Extension Score
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered._Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation._Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition._A score assigned to a Curie body segment to indicate the quantity of metastases.

When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.
